metadata.title: Recent Progress in the Applications of Vanadium-Based Oxides on Energy Storage: from Low-Dimensional Nanomaterials Synthesis to 3D Micro/Nano-Structures and Free-Standing Electrodes Fabrication

sections.text:
www.advenergymat.de
PROGRESS REPORT
1700547 (1 of 24) © 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
Recent Progress in the Applications of Vanadium-Based Oxides on Energy Storage: from Low-Dimensional Nanomaterials Synthesis to 3D Micro/Nano-Structures and Free-Standing Electrodes Fabrication Pengcheng Liu,* Kongjun Zhu,* Yanfeng Gao, Hongjie Luo, and Li Lu
DOI: 10.1002/aenm.201700547

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the economic, science and technology increasing at an amazing speed, energy has become one of the most important issues in the 21st century. In addition, the supply of fossil
With revolutionary electric vehicles and the smart grid fast developing, more advanced energy storage technologies become quite crucial issues. Li-ion batteries (LIBs) and Na-ion batteries (NIBs) are considered as the most promising electrochemical energy storage technologies. Low-dimensional nano-structural electrode materials can greatly increase the specific capacity, but they still suffer from poor cycling and rate performances due to their serious self-aggregations. Constructing 3D structures, such as micro/ nano-structures and free-standing electrodes, is a quite promising method to address the above issues. Such 3D structures can simultaneously avoid the disadvantages of low-dimensional nanomaterials, and preserve their advantages. As one group of promising high-capacity and low-cost electrode materials, vanadium-based oxides have exhibited an quite attractive electrochemical performance for energy storage applications in many novel works. However, their systematic reviews are quite limited, which is disadvantageous to their further development. Herein, this article provides an overview of vanadium-based oxides in the applications of LIBs and NIBs by focusing mainly on the aspect from low-dimensional nanomaterials synthesis to 3D micro/nano-structures and free-standing electrodes fabrication. Moreover, a feasible strategy to controllably fabricate the 3D micro/nano-structure for the whole vanadium-based oxides family is presented. Furthermore, and importantly, a quite promising solution method for the practical commercialized applications of vanadium oxides cathode materials in the future is proposed, i.e., fabricating the “vanadium oxides-based cathode/solid electrolyte/Li metal anode-type” all solid-state secondary-ion batteries.
Energy Storage

fuels is running out, and its burning also causes lots of serious environmental pollutions. So, the exploitation and development of clearer energy sources and more advanced energy storage technologies are quite crucial and urgent. The next-generation energy storage technologies should possess better performance, such as higher energy and power density, and longer cycling life.[1–9] Furthermore, some revolutionary applications, such as electric vehicles (EVs) and smart grid with one important function to store and release intermittent green energies (such as solar and wind), are greatly stimulating the fast development of energy storage technologies.[1–8,10]
Among various energy storage technologies, Li-ion batteries (LIBs) are considered as the most promising electrochemical energy storage technology due to their high energy density, long cycling life, no/little memory effect, low selfdischarge effect and good environmental friendly.[1–8,11] Since Sony for the first time realized the consumer applications of LIBs with the “rocking-chair” configuration in 1991, LIBs have dominated the entire electronic appliance market until now.[12,13] With the revolutionary EVs and large-scale energy storage system (ESS),
such as smart grid, fast developing, LIBs are also considered as the best choice.[14–16] However, portable electronics need a longer stand-by time, and EVs need a longer travel distance by one time, shorter charge time and longer service life, all of which put forward a higher requirement for LIBs.[14,17–19]
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1700547 (2 of 24)
So, it is urgent to exploit and develop the next-generation electrode materials of LIBs with the larger specific capacity and energy density, higher rate performance and power density, and longer cycling life. On the other hand, Na-ion batteries (NIBs) have become another important energy storage technology because of the abundance and low cost of the Na resource.[20–23] Moreover, NIBs possess the huge potential in the application of large-scale ESS. However, the radius of Na ions (≈0.102 nm) is larger than the one of Li ions (≈0.076 nm), which causes that most of successful electrode materials for LIBs are not suitable for NIBs.[23,24] So, it is also urgent to exploit and develop the novel high-performance electrode materials for NIBs.
As the typical layered-crystal structural materials, vanadiumbased oxides are considered as one of the most promising electrode materials for next-generation advanced electrochemical energy storage technology duo to their high specific capacity, abundance resource and low cost.[25–27] Vanadium-based oxides can be divided into vanadium oxides (such as V2O5, V6O13, V3O7·H2O@C, VO2 (B), V2O3 and so on) and vanadate (Li3VO4, NaVO2, NaV2O5 and so on). These have been a lot of applications of vanadium-based oxides on electrode materials of LIBs and NIBs. For example, as cathode materials of LIBs, centimeter-long V2O5 nanowires can deliver a high capacity of 351 mA h g−1.[28] As cathode materials of NIBs, single-crystalline bilayered V2O5 nanobelts can deliver a high capacity of 229 mA h g−1 at 80 mA g−1.[29] V3O7·H2O, VO2 (B) and VO2 (A) were controllably synthesized by a general method, and all of them exhibited a good electrochemical performance when used as cathode materials of LIBs.[30,31] It was found that Li3VO4 was a promising insertion anode material for LIBs with a low and safe discharge voltage (≈0.75 V vs Li/Li+ in average), and delivered a large capacity (≈323 mA h g−1).[32] Recently, it was also found that V2O3 was one new intercalation-type high-capacity anode materials with a high capacity of LIBs (≈732 mA h g−1) based on the ex situ XRD technology, and it also exhibited the potential for anode materials of NIBs.[33] By applying density functional theory (DFT) and electrochemical method, it was revealed that NaV2O5 was a new anode materials of NIBs with a high capacity (≈362 mA h g−1).[34]
Nanomaterials have shown huge advantages for various energy storage applications because of the ultra-large specific surface area and ultra-short diffusion path of ions/electrons.[35–38] Various low-dimensional nanostructures (such as 0D nanoparticles, 1D nanowires, 2D nanosheets, etc.),[38,39] especially graphene-like 2D ultrathin nanomaterials which result in a wealth of unprecedented functionalities,[40,41] have exhibited a large superiority for LIBs. However, recent reports reveal that nanostructured electrode materials have still some problems to be urgently addressed.[42–44] One main problem is that although exhibiting higher capacity, these simplex lowdimensional nanomaterials still suffer from the serious selfaggregation and pulverization during cycling caused by their quite large surface area and energy, which makes nanomaterials lose their advantages, and consequently leads to poor cycling and rate performance.[44–47] Furthermore, low-dimensional nanomaterials also have a low tap density duo to their large surface area, which hinders the application requiring high volumetric energy density.[48]
Pengcheng Liu will get his Ph.D. of material science and engineering from Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (NUAA) in June, 2017. His main research interests are the synthesis and applications of fascinating 3D structures, especially for vanadium oxide-based oxides, for advanced energy storage by applying the novel hydrothermal methods and electrospinning technology.
Kongjun Zhu is Professor of the State Key Laboratory of Mechanics and Control of Mechanical Structures in Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics (NUAA). He got his Ph.D. from Kochi University in 2005. After 2-year Assistant Professor in Tohoku University in Japan, he worked in NUAA from 2007
to now. His research interests include: (1) advanced nanostructured materials for the high-energy Li/Na-ion batteries; (2) high-dielectric BaTiO3-based composites for the novel energy storage system; (3) high-performance leadfree piezoelectric ceramics for the smart structure applications. He was supported by the Program for New Century Excellent Talent in 2009, and the Project of 333 high-level Talent in Jiangsu in 2013.
Li Lu is Professor at the National University of Singapore. He received his Ph.D. from Katholiek Universiteit Leuven, Belgium in 1989. After two years of postdoctoral study at the same university, he joined the National University of Singapore in 1991. His main research interests include rechargeable batteries, supercapacitors and ferroelectric ceramics.
To simultaneously develop the advantages of nanomaterials and overcome their disadvantages, building 3D micro/nanostructures, especially hierarchical porous ones, consisting of low-dimensional nanoscale building blocks, is a quite promising method to address the above issues.[25,42,44,49–55] 3D micro/nano-structures can inherit the superior characteristics
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1700547 (3 of 24)
of nano-building blocks, and synergistically gain additional benefits from the unique microscale secondary architectures, which can make electrode materials possess simultaneously high surface area and decent structural stability.[18,46,56–62] These fascinating features can effectively avoid the self-aggregation of active nanomaterials, and benefit the insertion/extraction of Li+, so that excellent cycling and rate performances can be obtained. For example, a 3D plum-pudding-like Si/C micro/ nano-composite was designed and synthesized via quasiindustrial-scale production, and it possessed excellent structural stability, which leads to the ultra-high initial Coulombic efficiency, high volumetric capacity and improved rate and cycling performance.[60] 3D porous LiFePO4/N-doped rGO composites were synthesized, and showed an ultra-high rate performance for LIBs cathode.[51] Hierarchical MoS2 microboxes constructed by ultrathin nanosheets are synthesized by a template-assisted strategy, and manifest high specific capacity and excellent cycling performance.[63] Furthermore, fabricating the free-standing electrodes with or without supporting matrix, which can be regarded as another kind of 3D structure, is also an effective method to avoid the self-aggregation of nanomaterials.[64–70] Moreover, the free-standing electrodes can also improve the electrochemical performance because of no addition of other inactive materials such as carbon black or polymer binder, and especially, they are necessary and important for the energy storage systems of the attractive smart wearable electrics.[64–67,69,70] For example, Zhang and co-workers proposed a facile and scalable in situ engraving Cu foil method to prepare highly dispersive and aligned porous Cu nanoarrays (CNAs).[69] When used as the free-standing anode of NIBs, CNAs exhibited superior electrochemical performance in terms of large capacity (over 640 mA h g−1), high rate and good cycle stability (up to 450 cycles) due to their advantages (i.e., porous structure, ample open space and short and fast electron transporting paths). A graphene paper electrode can deliver a higher capacity and better cycling than ones of graphene nanopowders, and also exhibit a good electrochemical performance when fabricated as a flexible full cell.[71]
In fact, there have been some excellent reports of vanadium-based oxides on the fabrication of their 3D micro/nanostructures and free-standing electrodes for the applications of LIBs and NIBs. For example, a unique 3D hierarchical porous sponge-like VO2 (B)@C micro/nano-structure was controllably synthesized, and delivered the excellent electrochemical
performance in terms of large capacity, long cycling and high rate as cathode materials of LIBs.[44] As cathode materials of LIBs, the 3D multi-shelled V2O5 hollow microspheres can deliver a specific discharge capacity of 447.9 and 402.4 mA h g−1 for the first and 100th cycle at 1 A g−1, respectively.[43] As cathode materials of NIBs, the second capacity of hierarchical V2O5 hollow nanospheres is 159 mA h g−1, and 141 mA h g−1 can be maintained after 100 cycles.[72] A free-standing electrode for LIBs of V2O5 encapsulated into carbon nanotubes not only delivered a stable capacity of 224 and 211 mA h g−1 for the first and 200th cycle respectively, but also exhibited an excellent electrochemical performance with a stable high capacity of ≈180 mA h g−1 at the flat or bend state when it was fabricated as flexible full cell.[73] However, the systematic and comprehensive summary and review about the applications of vanadium-based oxides in energy storage are quite limited, especially for the research progress aspect of the fabrication of their 3D micro/ nano-structures and free-standing electrodes.
Herein, focusing mainly on the aspect from low-dimensional nanomaterials synthesis to 3D micro/nano-structures and free-standing electrodes fabrication, this review provides an overview of the progress, problems, and future trends in the applications of vanadium-based oxides on LIBs and NIBs, as shown in Figure 1. Moreover, a feasible, effective and convenient route and strategy to controllably fabricate the 3D micro/ nanonano-structure for the whole vanadium-based oxides family is presented. Furthermore, importantly, a quite promising solution method for the practical commercialized applications of vanadium oxides cathode materials in the future is proposed, i.e., fabricating the “vanadium oxides-based cathode/ solid electrolyte/Li metal anode-type” all solid-state secondaryion batteries.

sections.heading: 2. Applications of Vanadium-Based Oxides on Li-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
Vanadium-based oxides possess multiple valence states. To our best knowledge, the valences of vanadium-based oxides that can be applied in LIBs is mainly between +5 and +3. They can be divided into vanadium oxides and vanadate. Representative vanadium oxides include V2O5, V6O13, V3O7·H2O, VO2 (B), V2O3 and so on. Representative vanadates include Li3VO4, Li0.3V2O5 and so on. Among then, V2O5, V6O13, V3O7·H2O
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547
and VO2 (B) are promising cathode materials of LIBs, and V2O3, Li3VO4 and Li0.3V2O5 are promising anode materials of LIBs. The detailed information, such as crystal structure, electrochemical applications and so on, of the above typical vanadium-based oxides is listed in Table 1. In this part, they will be discussed in detail mainly in the aspect from low-dimensional nanomaterials synthesis to 3D micro/nano-structures or free-standing electrodes fabrication for applications of LIBs. Moreover, their corresponding evolutions of electrochemical performance for LIBs are clearly listed in Table 2.

sections.heading: 2.1. V2O5
sections.text:
The crystal structure of V2O5 can be described as layers of VO5 square pyramids that share edges and corners (Figure 2a).
Their good layered crystal structure can facilitate the diffusion of Li-ions between the layers, so that V2O5 exhibits the quite attractive electrochemical performance when used as cathode materials of LIBs. Among various vanadium-based oxides, V2O5 have attracted the most attention. V2O5 will undergo the structural phase transformation from the α-V2O5, through ε-Li0.5V2O5, δ-LiV2O5, and γ-Li2V2O5 and finally to the ω-Li3V2O5 phase with 3 Li ions intercalation when discharged from 4 to 1.5 V, as shown in Equations (1), (2), (3), (4).[81,82]
During discharging from 4.0 to 3.4 V: 0.5 Li+ is intercalated
V O 0.5Li 0.5e Li V O2 5 0.5 2 5+ + →+ − (1)
During discharging from 3.4 to 3.2 V: another 0.5 Li+ is intercalated

0.5LiV O 0.5Li 0.5e LiV O2 5 2 5+ + →+ − (2)
During discharging from 3.2 to 2.3 V: the second Li+ is intercalated.
LiV O Li e Li V O2 5 2 2 5+ + →+ − (3)
During discharging from 2.3 to 1.5 V: the third Li+ is intercalated.
Li V O Li e Li V O2 2 5 3 2 5+ + →+ − (4)
However, when discharged below 2 V, irreversible ω-Li3V2O5 phase forms so that the capacity of V2O5 decreases rapidly when cycled between 4 and 1.5 V.[81,83] So, to avoid the formation of irreversible ω-Li3V2O5 and thereby improve the cycling performance, the appropriate voltage range of V2O5 is usually set as 4–2 V. In this voltage range, 2 Li ions can be reversibly intercalated/deintercalated into and from V2O5, and a theoretical capacity of 294 mA h g−1 is delivered.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Low-Dimensional Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Duo to the large surface area and short Li ion diffusion pathway of nanomaterials, various low-dimensional nano-structural V2O5, such as nanoribbons,[84] electrospun ultralong nanowires,[85] nanorods,[86] nanosheets,[87,88] nanotube[89] and so on, were firstly synthesized, and they exhibited much larger specific capacity than one of V2O5 bulk.[81,90–93] For example, Zhai and his co-workers synthesized one kind of centimeterlong V2O5 nanowires by hydrothermal method (Figure 3A).[28] As-synthesized V2O5 nanowires delivered a high capacity of 351 mA h g−1, which was ascribed to the larger specific surface area of nanomaterials. But, its capacity rapidly decreased to 175 mA h g−1 after only 20 cycles. To improve the cycling performance of V2O5 nanomaterials, some composite and coating methods were applied.[81,94] For example, Mai and his co-workers proposed a coating method to synthesize one kind
of cucumber-like V2O5/PEDOT&MnO2 nanowires by layerby-layer (LBL) method (Figure 3B).[94] As-synthesized V2O5/ PEDOT&MnO2 nanowires delivered an initial capacity of 179 mA h g−1 at a current density of 50 mA g−1, and a capacity of 166 mA h g−1 was maintained after 40 cycles, which revealed that such a multi-layer coating method could improve the cycling performance of V2O5 nanowires. However, it should be noted that although its cycling performance is improved, the capacity of coated V2O5 nanowires is decreased owing to the introduction of low-capacity PEDOT and MnO2 components. Furthermore, the capacity stability of coated V2O5 nanomaterials or V2O5 composites also need to be further improved when cycled at large current density.[81,94] The unsatisfactory cycling performance of low-dimensional V2O5 nanomaterials is mainly caused by their serous aggregations during cycling due to their large surface area and energy,[25,43,45,46] as mentioned in the introduction part.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. 3D Micro/Nano-Structures
sections.text:
So, to simultaneously develop the advantages of nanomaterials and overcome their disadvantages, and thereby improve evenly the electrochemical performance in the round, building 3D micro/nano-structures is a quite promising method to address the above issues.[18,25,42,49–55,60] Many excellent works on 3D V2O5 micro/nano-structures have been done in the recent years, and these 3D V2O5 micro/nano-structures can deliver the more attractive electrochemical performance in the round.[25,43,56,82,83,95–110] For example, 3D hierarchical V2O5 nanoflowers were synthesized through annealing the V10O24·nH2O nanoflowers precursors that were prepared by an electrochemical process.[103] Such V2O5 nanoflowers showed an improved capacity and cycling performance: a discharge capacity of 239 mA h g−1 was delivered after 50 cycles at 50 mA g−1, corresponding to 87% of the initial capacity. Lou and his co-workers synthesized the yolk-shelled V2O5 microspheres (Figure 4) via annealing the yolk-shelled VO2 microspheres with the same structure prepared by a template-free
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547
Figure 2. Crystal structures of representative vanadium-based oxides. a) V2O5, b) V6O13, c) V3O7·H2O, d) VO2 (B), e) NaVO2, f) NaV2O5.
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1700547 (6 of 24)
hydrothermal synthesis.[25] The electrochemical performance of as-synthesized yolk-shelled V2O5 microspheres was further improved. The initial capacity was 255 mA h g−1 at 300 mA g−1, and 89% of the initial capacity was maintained after 50 cycles. Furthermore, yolk-shelled V2O5 microspheres also showed a good rate performance: a stable capacity of ≈170 mA h g−1 could be obtained at 2400 mA g−1, and almost 100% of initial capacity was maintained when the current density was back to the small value. Wang and his co-workers proposed a groundbreaking anion-adsorption mechanism (Figure 5), in contrast to the conventional cation-adsorption process, to controllably synthesize several multi-shelled metal oxide hollow microspheres, especially the multishelled V2O5 hollow microspheres.[43] Assynthesized multi-shelled V2O5 hollow microspheres exhibited superb lithiumstorage properties: exceptionally high specific capacity (565.4 mA h g−1 at 50 mA g−1) and cycling stability (447.9 and 402.4 mA h g−1 for the first and 100th cycle at 1000 mA g−1, respectively). They also showed a remarkable rate performance: an amazingly high capacity of 331.8 mA h g−1 could be obtained

even cycled at 2000 mA g−1, almost 100% of initial capacity was maintained when the current density was back to the small value, and the subsequent cycling was still stable. The excellent electrochemical performance of multi-shelled V2O5 hollow microspheres was attributed to the abundant charge-storage sites, reduced transmission path and enhanced structural stability through building the 3D micro/nano-structures.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Free-Standing Electrodes
sections.text:
Fabricating the free-standing electrodes with or without supporting matrix is also an effective method to avoid the selfaggregation of nanomaterials, and free-standing electrodes are also quite necessary and important for the energy storage systems of the attractive smart wearable electrics.[64–67] Recently, some novel works on the free-standing V2O5 cathodes have been published, and these interesting free-standing V2O5 cathodes exhibited quite promising electrochemical performance and potential applications.[68,73,108,111–115] For example, ultrathin V2O5 nanowires were uniformly incorporated into graphene paper, so that V2O5/graphene paper electrode was finally obtained.[68] The as-fabricated V2O5/graphene paper electrode showed an amazingly excellent cycling performance: a capacity of 191.5 mA h g−1 was maintained when cycled at 1 A g−1 for 3000 cycles, and a capacity of 94.4 mA h g−1 can also be obtained when cycled at an even higher current density of 10 A g−1 for ultra-long 100000 cycles, implying that electrochemical processes in this free-standing composite electrode were extremely robust. Chao and his co-workers synthesized a V2O5/PEDOT core/shell nanobelts array on 3D ultrathin graphite foam (denoted as UGF-V2O5/PEDOT) by hydrothermal and electro-deposition methods.[113] As-fabricated UGF-V2O5/PEDOT exhibited excellent electrochemical performance: the specific capacities were 265 mA h g−1 and 168 mA h g−1 when cycled at 1.5 A g−1 and 18 A g−1, respectively, which can maintain 98% of their values up to 1000 cycles. Furthermore, it demonstrated outstanding power densities: an energy density of ca. 238 W h kg−1 at a power rate of 23 kW kg−1 was achieved, which was higher than those of reported aqueous-system supercapacitors. Yang and his coworkers designed and successfully fabricated an interwoven nanocable architecture constructed by V2O5 nanosheets encapsulated within multi-graphitic nanotubes (denoted as V2O5@G) through an electrospining method as a novel high performance flexible cathode for LIBs, as shown in Figure 6A.[73]
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547

A capacity of 211 mA h g−1 was obtained at 150 mA g−1 after 200 cycles, corresponding to the 91.7% of the initial capacity, and ≈90 mA h g−1 was still maintained at 30 A g−1. When it was fabricated as flexible full cell (Figure 6B), V2O5@G can also exhibit an excellent electrochemical performance with a stable high capacity of ≈180 mA h g−1 at the flat or bend state, and remarkably, an energy density of ca. 360 W h kg−1 at a power rate of 15.2 kW kg−1 was achieved. The reason why the electrochemical performances of V2O5 in the above freestanding electrodes are improved greatly is that the dispersion of V2O5 nanomaterials is preserved in a robust manner, and the serious self-aggregations are effectively avoided.[68]

sections.heading: 2.2. Mixed-Valence Vanadium Oxides
sections.text: Recent reports reveal that the mixed-valence vanadium oxides which exhibit the larger discharge capacity and energy density are more promising cathode materials.[46,116] V6O13 and V3O7·H2O are two kinds of the most representative mixed-valence vanadium oxides, and they are often taken as promising cathode materials of LIBs.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Low-Dimensional Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Low-Dimensional V6O13 Nanomaterials: As shown in Figure 2b, V6O13 consist of alternating single and double vanadium oxide layers. The single and double layers alternate in the V6O13 crystal structure and share corners, and thereby provide much more sites for Li ions intercalation. Moreover, V6O13 can electrochemically incorporate up to 8 Li per formula unit, which
results in a high theoretical specific capacity of 417 mA h g−1 (8 Li+ intercalation).[46] So, many V6O13 nanomaterials were synthesized as the cathode materials of LIBs.[74,117–124] For example, Zhou and his co-workers synthesized a V6O13 nanostructure from hydrated aerogel.[118] Its initial capacity was up to 385 mA h g−1, but the capacity deceased to ≈330 mA h g−1 after only 20 cycles. V6O13 nanorods and nanosheets were also synthesized by solvothermal and hydrothermal methods, respectively.[74,121] Unfortunately, the cycling performance of both of them were insufficient: the initial capacities of V6O13 nanorods and nanosheets were ≈325 and 330 mA h g−1, and the capacities decreased to ≈267 and 260 mA h g−1 after 50 cycles, respectively. The interlayer-expanded V6O13 nanosheets were synthesized to improve the cycling performance.[124] As-synthesized V6O13 nanosheets delivered a capacity of 191 mA h g−1 at 600 mA g−1 after 150 cycles, corresponding to 93.7% of initial capacity. It can also deliver a stable capacity when fabricated as a full cell. However, it should be noted that although the cycling performance was improved, the capacity was decreased. Furthermore, there are rare reports on the electrochemical reaction mechanism research of V6O13.
Low-Dimensional V3O7·H2O Nanomaterials: As shown in Figure 2c, the crystal structures of V3O7·H2O are basically analogous in terms of the edge-sharing VO6 octahedral units forming zigzag chains, which are connected by the chains of edge-sharing VO5 trigonal bi-pyramids by vertex sharing, then the joint chains of VO6–VO5 build a V3O8 layer. The existence of crystal water not only benefits to increase the interlayer space, but also make the crystal structures more robust. The theoretical specific capacity of V3O7·H2O is up to 378 or 470 mA h g−1 when 4 or 5 Li ions are intercalated, respectively. So, many V3O7·H2O
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547

nanomaterials were synthesized as the cathode materials of LIBs.[30,31,125–129] For example, a PEO/V3O7·H2O nanobelts composite was synthesized by hydrothermal method for 48 h.[129] The initial capacity of this kind of composite was 297 mA h g−1, but the capacity decreased rapidly to ≈170 mA h g−1 after 40 cycles, and the capacity retention was 58%. Zhou and his coworkers synthesized successfully the single crystal V3O7·H2O nanobelts by a hydrothermal method for 168 h.[126] Unfortunately, although V3O7·H2O nanobelts delivered a large initial discharge capacity of 409 mA h g−1 at 20 mA g−1, the capacity rapidly decreased to ≈260 mA h g−1 after only 20 cycles, corresponding to ≈63% of the initial capacity. In our previous work, we proposed a general method to controllably synthesize three kinds of well-crystalized vanadium oxides (VO2 (A), VO2 (B) nanosheets, and especially V3O7·H2O nanoribbons) based on a novel high-temperature mixing method (HTMM) under hydrothermal condition.[30,130] The initial capacity of as-synthesized V3O7·H2O nanoribbons was 244.6 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, and a capacity of 202 mA h g−1 can be obtained after 100 cycles, corresponding to 83% of the initial capacity. In our recent work,[31] to further improve the cycling performance of V3O7·H2O, a in situ carbon coating method was proposed to synthesize the ultrathin V3O7·H2O@C nanoribbons based on HTMM for just 1 h. As-prepared V3O7·H2O@C nanoribbons exhibited the improved electrochemical performance: the capacity was up to 319 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, a capacity of 262 mA h g−1 can be delivered at 500 mA g−1 with a capacity retention of 94% after 100 cycles, and especially their energy density was up to 800 W h kg−1. Although the capacity retention (it can also reach to 119% even when cycled at 3000 mA g−1 after 600 cycles) was improve greatly, a gradual capacity fading can be found in the later period of cycling, which might be mainly caused by the self-aggregation after finishing the activated process of beginning period. Furthermore, the charge–discharge behavior of V3O7·H2O is elucidated for the first time based on the ex situ XRD and ex situ XPS technologies, which reveals that 3.3 Li ions can be reversibly intercalated/deintercalated during multistep between 3.75 and 1.5 V.

sections.heading: 2.2.2. 3D Micro/Nano-Structures
sections.text:
To further improve the electrochemical performance of V6O13, some interesting 3D micro/nano-structures were synthesized.[46,131] For example, 3D V6O13 micro-flowers were synthesized by a hydrothermal method.[131] Their second discharge capacities are 202, 172.8, 158.3 and 152.9 mA h g−1 at the current densities of 100, 500, 750 and 1000 mA g−1, and capacity retention were 83.2%, 89.1%, 88.0% and 89.4% after 50 cycles, respectively. Yu and her co-workers synthesized 3D V6O13 nanotextiles assembled from interconnected nanogrooves via a facile solution-redox-based self-assembly route at room temperature, as shown in Figure 7.[46] The reversible capacities of as-synthesized 3D V6O13 nanotextiles were 326 mA h g−1 at 20 mA g−1 and 134 mA h g−1 at 500 mA g−1, and a capacity retention of above 80% after 100 cycles at 500 mA g−1 was also obtained. Furthermore, they also possessed a specific energy as high as 780 W h kg−1, 44−56% higher than those of conventional cathodes (such as LiMn2O4, LiCoO2, and LiFePO4). Although V6O13 can deliver a large specific capacity (326 mAh g−1), it should be noted that there is no obvious voltage platform in its charge/discharge curves like that of LiFePO4 at about 3.5 V. This phenomenon results in that the full cells, taking V6O13 as cathode materials of LIBs, can hardly deliver a stable and constant output voltage to make equipment work normally and effectively. In order to further apply V6O13 for energy storage, it is important and effective to investigate and understand the charge– discharge behavior and electrochemical reaction mechanism of V6O13. However, to our best knowledge, there is rare report on this aspect. Compared with V6O13, V3O7·H2O possesses the distinct flat charge–discharge voltage platform.[30] Unfortunately, to our best knowledge, no reports on 3D V3O7·H2O micro/nano-structures are found until now. It suggests that building 3D V3O7·H2O micro/nano-structures remains a challenge, and simultaneously also is an attractive research direction that is worthy to pay more efforts.
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1700547 (10 of 24)

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Free-Standing Electrodes
sections.text: Quite recently, several interesting works on free-standing mixed-valence vanadium oxides electrodes were reported.[75] For example, Tong, Balogun and their co-workers fabricated a steelmesh-supported V6O13 cathode by a facile two-step electrodeposition and immersion conversion route, as shown in Figure 8.[75] The thickness and loading of V6O13 can be controlled by an etched current collector-guided method, so that a free-standing electrode with appropriate loading amount of V6O13 was obtained, a better rate and cycling performances were delivered than those with more loading. However, the amount of reports on free-standing V6O13 electrode is much less than those of free-standing V2O5 electrode. Especially, there are no reports on the free-standing V3O7·H2O electrode. So, it also reveals that building free-standing mixed-valence vanadium oxides electrode is an attractive research direction that is worthy to pay more efforts.

sections.heading: 2.3. VO2 (B)
sections.text:
VO2 (B) is another vanadium oxide that has attracted a lot of research interests and attentions as cathode materials of LIBs. As shown in Figure 2d, the crystal structure of VO2 (B) consists of double layers of V4O10-type through stacking. In the crystal structure of VO2 (B), abundant tunnels form during the stacking of double layers, which can offer a rapid Li ions diffusion and insertion/deinsertion. VO2 (B) will also suffer from the serious capacity fading due to the formation of irreversible phase when cycled between a broad voltage range.[132] So, to avoid the formation of irreversible phase and thereby improve the cycling performance, the appropriate voltage range of VO2 (B) is often set as ≈3–2 V.[133] In this voltage range, 0.5 Li ions can be reversibly intercalated/deintercalated into and from VO2 (B) shown in Equation (5), and a theoretical capacity of 161 mA h g−1 is delivered.
VO B 0.5Li 0.5e Li VO B2 0.5 2( ) ( )+ + →+ − (5)

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Low-Dimensional Nanomaterials
sections.text: Various low-dimensional VO2 (B) nanomaterials have been synthesized.[30,45,76,132,134–139] For example, Baudrin, Tarascon and their co-workers synthesized a nanotextured VO2 (B).[132] This VO2 (B) nanotextures can deliver a high initial capacity of ≈520 mA h g−1 when cycled at 50 mA g−1 between 4.0 and 1.5 V, but the capacity decreased rapidly to ≈480 mA h g−1 after only 10 cycles. The fast capacity fading was caused by the improper voltage window.[132] To improve the cycling performance of VO2 (B), the carbon-coated VO2 (B) nanosheets were synthesized.[76] When cycled at 100 mA g−1 between 2.0 and 4.0 V, the initial capacity of VO2 (B)@C was ≈160 mA h g−1, and a capacity of ≈125 mA h g−1 was maintained after 50 cycles, corresponding to a capacity retention of 78%. In our previous work, wellcrystalized VO2 (B) nanosheets were synthesized by a general method based on HTMM.[30] They can deliver a more stable cycling: the initial capacity was 146 mA h g−1 when cycled at 100 mA g−1 between 3.0 and 2.0 V, and 83% of the initial capacity was maintained after 100 cycles.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. 3D Micro/Nano-Structures
sections.text:
To further improve the electrochemical performance of VO2 (B), more and more research interests were being paid on building 3D VO2 (B) micro/nano-structures.[25,133,140–144] Various 3D VO2 (B) micro/nano-structures with abundant morphologies were synthesized, and showed a greatly improved electrochemical performances in the round. For example, Cao and his co-workers synthesized 3D micro/nano-structural VO2 (B) mesocrystals through a solvothermal method.[142] When cycled at 150 mA g−1 between 2.0 to 3.8 V, the initial capacity of VO2 (B) mesocrystals was 258 mA h g−1, and a high capacity of ≈194 mA h g−1 was maintained after 50 cycles. A hybrid nanostructural VO2 (B) buffered by nanoscrolls was synthesized by Mai and his co-workers to further improve the cycling performance.[133] The initial and 100th capacities of such VO2
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547

Fabrication process of 3D free-standing steel-mesh-supported V6O13 as cathode of LIBs: illustrations for the top-down etching of a flat surface to give a rugged surface and the subsequent growth of V6O13, including the etching process of the current collector, electrodeposition of the MnO2 precursor, and its conversion into V6O13. SEM images at each stage are shown. Reproduced with permission.[75] Copyright 2017, Royal Society of Chemistry.
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1700547 (11 of 24)
(B) hybrid nanostructures are 158 and 139 mA h g−1, respectively, corresponding to a capacity retention of 85%. They also showed a good rate performance: a capacity of 98 mA h g−1 was obtained at large 2000 mA g−1, and 98.7% of the capacity was recovered when the current was turned back to 100 mA g–1. Mai and his co-workers further proposed and synthesized an interesting VO2 (B) hollow microspheres self-assembled by nano wires (Figure 9).[45] As-synthesized VO2 (B) hollow microspheres exhibited the higher specific capacity (200 and 163 mA h g−1 at 100 and 1000 mA g−1, respectively) and better cycling stability (90% after 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1 and 73% after 1000 cycles at 1000 mA g−1, respectively). They also showed an excellent rate performance: a high capacity of 134 mA h g−1 could be obtained even cycled at 2000 mA g−1, 93% of initial capacity was maintained when the current density was back to the small value, and the subsequent cycling was still stable. In our recent published work, based on the novel HTMM, we proposed a facile “hydrolysis-controllable crystallization” strategy to controllably synthesize different dimensional (i.e., 1D, 2D, and 3D) VO2 (B) nanostructures (Figure 10), especially a unique 3D hierarchical porous sponge-like micro-bundles (SLMBs) self-assembled from ultrathin VO2 (B)@C nanosheets (denoted as VO2 (B)@CSLMBs).[44] By applying the density functional theory (DFT) calculation, the intrinsic VO2 (B) crystallization behavior and

controllable synthesis mechanism of micro/nano-structures are revealed for the first time. As-synthesized VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs exhibited the quite attractive electrochemical performance (i.e., high capacity, long life and high rate). Their discharge capacity was still up to 206 mA h g−1 after 160 cycles at 100 mA g−1, corresponding to 105% of the initial capacity. Even at a large 1000 mA g−1, it still exhibits a high retention of 104% after long-term 1000 cycles with an initial capacity of 137 mA h g−1.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Free-Standing Electrodes
sections.text:
On the other hand, some interesting free-standing VO2 (B) electrodes were fabricated to improve the electrochemical performance of VO2 (B).[77,145,146] For example, a free-standing carbon fiber cloth@VO2 (B) was fabricated as a high mass-loading cathode of LIBs, and exhibited a good electrochemical performance.[146] When cycled at 1000 mA g−1, the initial capacity of carbon fiber cloth@VO2 (B) was 145 mA h g−1, a capacity retention of over 90% was obtained after 200 cycles. It also showed a high rate capability at high current densities up to 2000 mA g−1. Tong and co-workers fabricated one interesting carbon cloth-supported carbon quantum dot surface-engineered VO2 interwoven nanowires (denoted as C-VOCQD), as free-standing cathode of LIBs.[147] As-fabricated C-VOCQD exhibited the excellent electrochemical performance in terms of large capacity, long cycling and high rate. Its reversible capacity was up to 402 mA h g−1 at 0.3 C. Even at high 60 C, a capacity of 173 mA h g−1 was still delivered, and more than 100% of its initial capacity can be retained after 500 cycles. Fan, Shen and their co-workers fabricated a quite interesting graphene quantum dots coated VO2 (B) arrays on the graphene foam (denoted as GVG) as the high-performance cathode of LIBs,
as shown in Figure 11.[77] The capacity of as-fabricated GVG was up to 421 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1. When cycled at 18 A g−1, the initial capacity of GVG was still up to ≈200 mA h g−1, and 94% of initial capacity was maintained after 1500 cycles. Even at a ultra-large current density of 36 A g−1, a capacity of ≈151 mA h g−1 can also be delivered. Then, they fabricated an interesting grapheme foam-supported highly conductive coating shell (i.e., hydrogen molybdenum bronze, HMB)-coated VO2 nanoflake arrays (denoted as GF + VO2/HMB) as freestanding cathode, and as-fabricated GF + VO2/HMB also exhibited the excellent electrochemical performance for LIBs.[148]

sections.heading: 2.4. V2O3
sections.text: The crystal structure of V2O3 is shown in Figure 12a.[149] It can be strikingly seen that abundant tunnels are present in the crystal structure of V2O3, which facilitates the intercalation/deintercalation of Li ions and endows it with a theoretical capacity as high as 356 mA h g−1 (2 Li+ intercalation).[149] Furthermore, in the 3-dimensional V–V framework of V2O3, the V3d electrons could itinerate along the V–V chains, thus rendering it to take on an intrinsic metallic behavior, which also makes them exhibit a high conductivity.[149] In recent years, V2O3 has been attracting more and more attention as the highperformance anode materials of LIBs.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. Low-Dimensional Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Many V2O3 nanomaterilas have been synthesized as anode materials of LIBs.[78,149–151] For example, Xie and her co-workers synthesized the highly ordered lamellar
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1700547 (13 of 24)
V2O3-based hybrid nanorods by a hydrothermal method (Figure 12b–c).[149] When used as anode materials of aqueous LIBs, V2O3-based hybrid nanorods delivered a capacity up to 131 mA h g−1, almost two times higher than that of bulk V2O3 (73.9 mA h g−1), and 88% of initial capacity was retained after 50 cycles. Huang and co-workers synthesized the carbon-coated V2O3 nanobelts through annealing the V3O7·H2O@C and VO2 (B)@C nanobelts, respectively, and applied them in organic LIBs.[78,151] For the V2O3@C nanobelts prepared from VO2 (B)@C nanobelts, their initial capacity was 176 mA h g−1, but the capacity decreased rapidly to 67 mA h g−1 after 89 cycles.[151] For the V2O3@C nanobelts prepared from V3O7·H2O@C nanobelts, its initial capacity was 171 mA h g−1, but only 48% of initial capacity could be retained after 60 cycles.[78]

sections.heading: 2.4.2. 3D Micro/Nano-Structures
sections.text:
Quite recently, some novel works on the 3D V2O3 micro/nanostructures were published, and these interesting V2O3 micro/ nano-structures exhibited the better electrochemical performance.[152,79] For example, the in situ carbon-coated yolk− shell V2O3 microspheres were synthesized via a template-free polyol solvothermal method.[152] The cycling performance of such yolk−shell V2O3@C microspheres was improved greatly. They showed a capacity of 437.5 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1, corresponding to 92.6% of the initial capability. Another homologous V2O3/C box-in-box micro/nano-structure was synthesized by a template-assisted hydrothermal
method based on a hollow carbon micro-box, as shown in Figure 13.[79] This kind of box-in-box V2O3/C micro/nanostructures exhibited the excellent long cycling and high rate performances as anode materials of LIBs. They can deliver a high reversible capacity of 641 mA h g−1 even after 1200 cycles at 1000 mA g−1, Even when cycled at a large current density of 5000 mA g−1, a capacity of over 400 mA g−1 was obtained. Furthermore, when fabricated as a full cell with taking V2O5 box as cathode materials, a stable capacity was also obtained. In our recent published work, by taking the sponge-like VO2 (B)@C micro-bundles (i.e., VO2 (B)@C-SLMBs mentioned in section 2.3.2, Figure 10) as precursor, a hierarchical porous V2O3@C micro/nano-structure with similar structures assembled by nanosheets was synthesized by a self-reducing method through applying the reducing effect of carbon in precursors during annealing, as shown in Figure 14a.[33] Also, a hierarchical porous V2O5@C micro/nano-structure with similar structures was synthesized by a in situ oxidizing method through annealing under Air, as shown in Figure 14b. Such a V2O3@C micro/nano-structure can also deliver a large capacity of 732 mA h g−1 without capacity loss at 100 mA g−1 even after 136 cycles. Furthermore, the electrochemical mechanism of V2O3 is investigated by ex situ XRD technology, which revealed that V2O3 was a new intercalation-type highcapacity anode material of LIBs.
Unfortunately, to our best knowledge, no reports on freestanding V2O3 electrodes are found until now. It suggests that fabricating free-standing V2O3 electrodes remains a challenge, and simultaneously also is an attractive research direction that is worthy to pay more efforts.
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547

sections.heading: 2.5. Vanadate
sections.text:
Many kinds of vanadates have been applied as electrode materials for organic or aqueous LIBs, such as LixV2O5,[26,153,154] LiV3O8,[155–157] NaV6O15,[158] Na0.33V2O5,[154] LiCuVO4,[159] NiV3O8,[160] CuV2O5,[161] and so on. Recently, another vanadate Li3VO4 has attracted broad research interests and attention, and was considered as a very promising insertion anode material for LIBs with a low and safe discharge voltage (≈0.75 V vs Li/Li+ in average), and delivered a large capacity (≈323 mA h g−1), as shown in Figure 15.[32,80,162–164] The crystal structure of Li3VO4 is shown in Figure 15a. It consists of oxygen atoms in approximately hexagonal close packing; and the cations occupy ordered tetrahedral sites.[32] All the tetrahedra point towards the up orientation along the c axis, and connect with each other by cornersharing only. In the structure, Li ions occupy two different tetrahedral sites, V5+ ions occupy a third tetrahedral site, there is still many empty cationic sites which might be capable of further insertion of Li ions. Quite recently, a high-quality review on Li3VO4 was published by Zhou and his co-workers.[162] So, in this part of the present article, we just give the brief introduction from the aspect of the synthesis of Li3VO4 nanomaterials and micro/nano-structures.
Zhou and his co-workers synthesized pure Li3VO4 by a solidstate method.[32] They found that compared with the common graphite anode materials, Li3VO4 possessed a higher discharge voltage (≈0.75 V vs Li/Li+ in average), which reveals that Li3VO4 is safe, as shown in Figure 15b. Compared with another safe Li4Ti5O12, Li3VO4 delivered a higher capacity ≈323 mA h g−1. More importantly, they also found that Li3VO4 exhibited an intercalation-type electrochemical performance with a small volume change during cycling based on the ex situ XRD investigation. So, based on these results, Li3VO4 is one kind of promising safer and high-capacity intercalation-type anode materials of LIBs. To obtain better electrochemical performance of Li3VO4, Cao and his co-workers synthesized the carbon-encapsulated Li3VO4 by a facile environmentally benign solid-state method with organic metallic precursor VO(C5H7O2)2 being chosen as both V and carbon sources yielding a core–shell nanostructure with lithium introduced in the subsequent annealing
process.[164] They exhibited the high rate capability (a reversible capability of 450, 340, 169, and 106 mA h g−1 at 0.1 C, 10 C, 50 C, and 80 C, respectively) and long cyclic performance (80% capacity retention after 2000 cycles at 10 C). To further improve the electrochemical performance of Li3VO4, Wu, Wang and their co-workers prepared a 3D hollow Li3VO4, micro-box/graphene composite by a one-pot and template-free in situ hydrothermal method.[80] Such a 3D Li3VO4, micro-box/graphene composite showed an excellent electrochemical performance as the anode materials for LIBs. They can deliver a reversible capacity of 223 mA h g−1 even at 20 C (1 C = 400 mA g−1). After 500 cycles at 10 C there is no evident capacity fading. The above results reveal that the electrochemical performance of micro/ nano-structural Li3VO4 can be improved effectively.
Unfortunately, to our best knowledge, no reports on freestanding Li3VO4 electrodes are found until now. It suggests that fabricating free-standing Li3VO4 electrodes remains a challenge, and simultaneously also is an attractive research direction that is worthy to pay more efforts.

sections.heading: 3. Applications of Vanadium-Based Oxides on Na-Ion Batteries
sections.text:
The researches of vanadium-based oxides in applications of NIBs are relatively less compared with those in applications of LIBs. A main reason is that the radius (≈0.102 nm) of Na ions is larger than that (≈0.076 nm) of Li ions, so that it is more difficult to apply vanadium-based oxides as electrode materials of NIBs with high electrochemical performances. However, the mature electrode materials that can be applied in NIBs are still quite limited. So, to exploit the more suitable electrode materials of NIBs, it is worthy to pay more research attention, efforts and interests on the applicators of the promising vanadium-based oxides in NIBs. In fact, many groundbreaking works have already been reported. In these novel works, vanadium-based oxides exhibit quite promising and attractive electrochemical performances as electrode materials of NIBs. Until now, vanadium-based oxides that can be used as electrode materials of NIBs can be divided into vanadium oxides and vanadate. Representative vanadium
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547
Figure 15. Crystal structure and electrochemical performance of Li3VO4 as anode materials of LIBs. a) Crystal structure, b) comparison of Li3VO4 with two typical insertion anode materials of Li4Ti5O12 and graphite in terms of intercalation potential, specific capacity and energy density. Reproduced with permission.[32] Copyright 2013, Wiley.
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1700547 (16 of 24)
oxides include V2O5, V6O13, V3O7·H2O, VO2 (B) and so on. Representative vanadates include NaxVO2, NaV2O5 and so on. Among then, V2O5, V6O13, V3O7·H2O, VO2 (B) and NaxVO2 are promising cathode materials of NIBs, and V2O5 and NaV2O5 are promising anode materials of NIBs. In this part, they will be discussed in detail mainly in the aspect from low-dimensional nanomaterials synthesis to 3D micro/nano-structures or free-standing electrodes fabrication for applications of NIBs. Moreover, their corresponding evolutions of electrochemical performance for NIBs are clearly listed in Table 3.

sections.heading: 3.1. V2O5
sections.text: Because the radius of Na ions is larger than that of Li ions, the orthorhombic V2O5 that can be used in LIBs doesn’t deliver a sufficient electrochemical performance, especially the discharge specific capacity. For example, the reversible capacity of orthorhombic V2O5 is just ≈70 mA h g−1 at 80 mA g−1.[29]

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Low-Dimensional Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Many interesting methods are proposed to improve the electrochemical performance of V2O5 cathode materials for NIBs.[29,168–173] A bilayered V2O5 was synthesized with adjustable intralayer spacing that accommodates intercalation of Na ions.[168] It can deliver a reversible capacity of 250 mA h g−1, and its energy density was up to 760 W h kg−1. Wang, Su and their co-workers used a facile hydrothermal method to synthesize the single-crystalline bilayered V2O5 nanobelts, as shown in Figure 16A.[29] This kind of V2O5 nanobelts possessed a large (001) interlayer spacing (≈11.53 Å), which can well accommodate Na-ion insertion and extraction. So, they exhibited a high capacity of 231.4 mA h g−1 at 80 mA g−1. To increase the interlayer spacing of V2O5, Mai and his co-workers synthesized a V2O5·nH2O xerogel via a facile freeze-drying process.[171] The interlayer spacing of V2O5·nH2O xerogel was much larger than that of orthorhombic V2O5. So, V2O5·nH2O xerogel exhibited a improved electrochemical performance: a high initial capacity of 338 mA h g−1 at 0.05 A g−1 was obtained, and a high-rate capacity of 96 mA h g−1 at 1.0 A g−1 was also
delivered. To improve the electrochemical performance, Chung and co-workers synthesized a nanosized V2O5/C composite.[172] The composite exhibited a discharge capacity of 255 and 160 mA h g−1 at 0.05 and 1 C, respectively. More importantly, the electrochemical reaction mechanism of V2O5 during the insertion/extraction of Na ions was investigated using ex situ XRD and synchrotron based near edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) spectroscopy. The ex situ XRD results reveal that NaV2O5 was a major phase with minor Na2V2O5 phase at the fully discharged state. Upon insertion of Na ion into the interlayers of V2O5, it was confirmed that the lattice parameter of c was increased by 9.09%, corresponding to the increase in the unit-cell volume of 9.2%. Furthermore, it was also found that V2O5 can deliver a capacity of 200 mA h g−1 in the voltage range ≈0.01–1.5 V, which revealed that V2O5 was also a promising anode materials of NIBs.[174]

sections.heading: 3.1.2. 3D Micro/Nano-Structures
sections.text:
Some interesting 3D V2O5 micro/nano-structures were also synthesized to greatly improve the electrochemical performance of V2O5 for NIBs.[72,165,175,176] For example, Ji and coworkers fabricated a 3D orthorhombic V2O5/nanoporous carbon composite by ambient hydrolysis deposition.[175] This composite delivered a stable capacity of ≈200 mA h g−1 at 170 mA g−1, and retained a capacity of over 90 mA h g−1 at 640 mA g−1. To improve the electrochemical performance, Wang, Su and their co-workers synthesized the hierarchical orthorhombic V2O5 hollow nanospheres by annealing vanadyl ethylene glycolate hollow hierarchical nanospheres precursors that were synthesized via a template-free polyol-induced solvothermal process.[72] When applied as cathode materials of NIBs, the V2O5 hollow nanospheres delivered a reversible specific discharge capacity of ≈150 mA h g−1, which is equal to one Na ion insertion per V2O5 formula unit. Then, they further synthesized hierarchical V2O5 spheres by a hydrothermal method, as shown Figure 16B.[165] When used as anode materials of NIBs, the as-prepared hierarchical V2O5 exhibited a discharge capacity of 271 mA h g−1 at 40 mA g−1, and 177 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles. Even at high current densities, they also still delivered high capacity and superior cyclability (179 and 140 mA h g−1
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1700547 (17 of 24)
discharge capacities at 640 and 1280 mA g−1, respectively). The improved electrochemical performances of these interesting 3D V2O5 micro/nano-structures could be ascribed to their special porous hollow hierarchical architecture.
Unfortunately, to our best knowledge, no reports on freestanding V2O5 electrodes for NIBs are found until now. It suggests that fabricating free-standing V2O5 electrodes that can be used as the electrodes of NIBs remains a challenge, and simultaneously also is an attractive research direction that is worthy to pay more efforts.

sections.heading: 3.2. Vanadate
sections.text:
Some vanadates have been applied as electrode materials for NIBs, such as NaxVO2,[167,177–180] NaV2O5,[34] NaV6O15,[181] Na2V6O16,[182] Na1.1V3O7.9[183] and so on.
Among them, NaV2O5 is the only anode material of NIBs. The crystal structure of NaV2O5 is shown in Figure 2e. It can be described as that the base-faced layers are constructed by the connection of (V2O4)n zigzag double chains consisting of squarepyramidal VO5 units, then the crystal structure of NaV2O5 forms by the stacking of these layers. Na ions also lie between these layers, and importantly, the well-supported interlayer provides more intercalation sites and a fast diffusion pathway for Na ions. In our previous work, a 3D NaV2O5 mesocrystal was controllably synthesized by a two-step hydrothermal method, as shown in Figure 17.[34] By applying DFT and electrochemical method, it was revealed that NaV2O5 was a new anode material of NIBs with a high capacity (≈362 mA h g−1).
Among those cathode materials of vanadate for NIBs, NaxVO2 has attracted the most attention duo to their attractive layered crystal structure. The crystal structure of NaVO2 is shown in Figure 2f. It can be described as that the base-faced layers consist of VO6 octahedrons, and Na ions lie between interlayers. The crystal structure of NaVO2 is as similar as that of the common LiCoO2, a very important cathode material for LIBs. The stable interlayer structure can facilitate the intercalation and diffusion of Na ions. A lot of attentions were paid on their crystal structure transformation and electrochemical mechanism.[167,177–180] For example, Delmas and co-workers provided the detailed phase diagram of the layered P2-NaxVO2 system confirmed by the electrochemical intercalation/deintercalation in NIBs and in situ XRD characterizations, as shown in Figure 18.[167] It was found that there were four main single-phase domains within 0.5 ≤ x ≤ 0.9 range. During the sodium intercalation (deintercalation), they differed from one another in the sodium/ vacancy ordering between VO2 layers, which leaded to the commensurable or incommensurable superstructures. The electrochemical curve suggested that three peculiar compositions exhibited special structures for x = 1/2, 5/8 and 2/3. Recently, Na1.1V3O7.9 has caught attention as a promising cathode material for NIBs. For example, Zhang and co-workers synthesized the pure single crystalline Na1.1V3O7.9 nanobelts (denoted as NVONBs) through a facile and low-temperature strategy by using cheap resources.[183] By applying the Rietveld refinement method, they found for the first time that NVONBs possessed the layered crystal structure that could facilitate Na-ions insertion/extraction. So, when used as cathode materials of NIBs, NVONBs exhibited high specific capacity (173 mA h g−1), good cycling and rate performances, and high Coulombic efficiency. Furthermore, the phase transformation process of NVONBs during charging/discharging was also researched by ex situ XRD and XPS techniques.
Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547

sections.heading: 3.3. VO2 (B), Mixed-Valence Vanadium Oxides and V2O3
sections.text:
A few of interesting and novel works also reported that VO2 (B), V3O7·H2O and V6O13 were applied as the cathode materials of NIBs.[31,77,131,166] The single crystalline VO2 nanosheets were synthesized by a simple hydrothermal method.[166] Assynthesized VO2 nanosheets showed a good rate performance. They can still deliver a discharge capacity of 108 mA h g−1 even at a large current density of 500 mA g−1. Tong and coworkers used the C-VOCQD (see section 2.3.3) as the highperformance free-standing cathode of NIBs.[147] Its reversible capacity was up to 321 mA h g−1 at 0.3 C. Even at high 60 C, a capacity of 132 mA h g−1 was still delivered, and 80% of its initial capacity can be retained after 200 cycles. Especially, the energy and power densities of C-VOCQD for Na storage reach 264 W h kg−1 and 41,333 W kg−1, respectively. Fan, Shen and their co-works also applied the interesting GVG (mentioned at the part of 2.3.3) as the high-performance cathode of NIBs, as shown in Figure 11.[77] The as-fabricated GVG also delivered the excellent electrochemical performance. The Na storage capacity was up to 306 mA h g−1 at 100 mA g−1, and a capacity of more than 110 mA h g−1 after 1500 cycles at 18 A g−1. As for V6O13, 3D V6O13 micro-flowers (see section 2.2.2) were also used as the cathode materials of NIBs.[131] They
Until now, there are rare reports on the applications of other mixed-valence vanadium oxides and V2O3. Meanwhile, in our recent published works, we had a try to apply V2O3@C micro/ nano-structures as electrode materials of NIBs, and illustrated the detailed assembly process of NIBs.[33] It was excitingly found that V2O3@C micro/nano-structures were the promising anode materials of NIBs: the reversible capacity was 239 mA h g–1, the capacity was stable during the following cycles, and the capacity retention was up to 84% after 35 cycles. Furthermore, in another recent published work,[31] it was found that V3O7·H2O@C nanoribbons were the promising cathode materials of NIBs, as shown in Table 3.
Based on the above summary and overview, it should be noted that compared with LIBs, the researches of vanadium-based oxides in the applications of NIBs are insufficient. However, the existing novel works reveal that vanadium-based oxides could become the quite promising and attractive electrode materials of NIBs. So, to exploit the more suitable electrode materials of NIBs, it is worthy to pay more research attention and efforts on the synthesis of vanadium-based oxides nanomaterials, micro/ nano-structures or free-standing electrodes, and further explore their possibility in the applications of high-performance NIBs.

sections.heading: 4. Outlook
sections.text:
It is without doubt that energy storage has become continuously hot and urgent issue paid by huge attentions in the 21th century. Among various energy storage technologies, LIBs and NIBs are considered as the most promising electrochemical energy storage technologies. With some revolutionary energy storage applications (such as electric vehicles, large-scale ESS and so on) fast developing at an amazing speed, the higher demands are put forward for LIBs and NIBs. The next-generation LIBs and NIBs should possess better performance, such as higher energy and power density, longer cycling life and so on. Vanadium-based oxides are considered as one of the most promising electrode materials for the next-generation advanced batteries duo to their high specific capacity, high energy density, abundance resource and low cost. A lot of low-dimensional vanadium-based oxides have been synthesized, and exhibit exceptional high specific capacity. Even in the recent years, more and more research interests and attentions are paid on the fabrication of 3D micro/nanostructures and free-standing electrodes of vanadium-based oxides to further improve the electrochemical performance. Moreover, various interesting attractive 3D micro/nano-structures and freestanding electrodes of vanadium-based oxides are successfully fabricated, so that their electrochemical performances are greatly improved evenly in the round. However, it should be noted that although many vanadium-based oxides have exhibited the
Figure 18. Evolution of the electrochemical behavior of P2-NaxVO2 system as cathode materials of NIBs. a) Evolution of cell voltage as a function of sodium content in NaxVO2 over the 0.5 ≤ x ≤ 0.92 range, b) in situ XRD pattern recorded during the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique experiments. Reproduced with permission.[167] Copyright 2013, Nature Publishing Group.
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1700547 (20 of 24)Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547
satisfactory electrochemical performances, there remains some attractive challenges for the more mature developments and applications of vanadium-based oxides, which is worthy to overcome by paying more interests, attention and efforts.
1) The present structure of commercial LIBs is “cathode (active materials are Li-including LiFePO4, LiCoO2, etc.)-liquid organic electrolyte-anode (active material is graphite)”, and the free Li ions in such a battery system are only supplied from the Li-including cathode materials. Thus, although vanadium oxides (such as V2O5, VO2 (B), V6O13, V3O7·H2O) are quite promising cathode materials with high capacity and energy density, they cannot be applied in the present LIBs because of the deletion of Li ions, which seriously hinders their further development and practical commercialized applications. All solid-state Li-ion batteries are a quite important and promising development direction of LIBs, especially the one taking Li metal as anode. So, to facilitate and realize the practical commercialized applications of vanadium oxides cathode materials, it would be one of the possible and promising solution methods to fabricate the “vanadium oxides-based cathode/solid electrolyte/Li metal-type” all solid-state secondary-ion batteries, as shown in the right part of Figure 1. In such an all solid-state LIBs, Li metal anode can supply the free Li ions, so that cells can work normally and effectively. Furthermore, this kind of all solid-state LIBs also possesses other special advantages: the safety can be greatly confirmed and bad effect of Li dendrites can be almost avoided by the use of solid electrolyte instead of unsafe liquid electrolyte, and the energy density can be increased greatly by the use of Li metal anode due to the increased output voltage. Also, a similar structural all solid-state NIBs can be fabricated. 2) Although there are many synthesis methods to prepare 3D micro/nano-structural vanadium-based oxides, there
methods are often different, and especially one method is just applied for the synthesis of one specially appointed vanadium-based oxide. So, it is a huge mission to synthesize the 3D micro/nano-structures for the whole vanadium-based oxides family because a lot of different synthesis methods have to be used to synthesize a variety of vanadium-based oxides. A feasible, effective and convenient route and strategy to controllably fabricate the 3D micro/nano-structure for the whole vanadium-based oxides family is that VO2 (B) micro/nano-structures with different morphologies are firstly controllably synthesized based on understanding its intrinsic nucleation, growth and reaction behavior, and then they can be easily reduced or oxidized as other valence-state similar-morphology vanadium oxides (without Li2CO3 or LiOH during annealing) or vanadates (with Li2CO3 or LiOH during annealing) by a simple annealing treatment, as shown in Figure 19. The reason is that the valence states of vanadium-based oxides that can be applied for the energy storage are from +5 to +3, and the valence states
(+4) of VO2 (B) is just in the middle. So that, VO2 (B) can be more easily conveniently reduced as low-valence vanadiumbased oxides, or oxidized as high-valence vanadium-based oxides, as shown in Figure 14. So, this kind of route and strategy is more time-saving, effort-saving and highly effective. 3) Fabricating the free-standing electrodes with or without supporting matrix is also an effective method to avoid the selfaggregation of nanomaterials, and free-standing electrodes are also quite necessary and important for the energy storage systems of the attractive smart wearable electrics. Although many interesting and novel works on the fabrication of freestanding vanadium-based oxides electrodes, some promising and important vanadium-based oxides (such as Li3VO4, V2O3, V3O7·H2O and so on) are not still fabricated as free-standing electrodes, which reveals that it remains a challenge, and is simultaneously also an attractive research direction that is worthy to pay more efforts. 4) Recently, some novel multi-electron transfer secondary battery systems, such as magnesium-ion batteries (MIBs) and aluminum-ion batteries (AIBs), have attracted more and more attention due to possible higher specific capacity and energy density, and are consider as potential candidates of post LIBs.[184–188] Some vanadium-based oxides are also excitingly found to be the quite promising electrode materials of AIBs and MIBs.[186,189–193] For example, Bai, Lu, Amine and their co-workers synthesized a Ni foam-supported V2O5 (denoted as Ni-V2O5) as free-standing cathode of AIBs, and Ni-V2O5 delivered an initial discharge capacity of 239 mA h g−1.[191] Tepavcevic, Rajh and their co-workers synthesized a carbon nanofoam-supported nanostructured bilayered V2O5 with a capacity of 240 mA h g−1 as the free-standing cathode of MIBs, and they also investigated the intercalation/ deintercalation process of Mg ions.[193] So, it is worthy to pay more attention to explore the application possibility of more
Figure 19. Schematic diagram of a feasible, effective and convenient route and strategy to controllably fabricate the 3D micro/nano-structure for the whole vanadium-based oxides family.
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1700547 (21 of 24)Adv. Energy Mater. 2017, 1700547
interesting vanadium-based oxides with different morphology and structure for electrode materials of multi-electron transfer secondary battery. 5) Recently, except vanadium-based oxides, some other vanadium-based compounds, such as vanadium nitrides,[194–202] vanadium sulfides,[203–206] vanadium carbides,[207] and so on, have also attracted increasing attention for the application of energy storage in recent years due to their renowned chemical and physical properties. For example, VN is a typical vanadium nitride, and possesses the high electrical conductivity (≈106 s m−1) and large theoretical specific capacity (≈1043 mA h g−1), which make it a promising candidate as an anode material for LIBs.[194,201] However, it should be noted that VN lacks a flat and stable charge–discharge voltage platform, which results in many difficulties and problems for the practical commercialized applications as full cells. As for vanadium sulfides, a typical VS4 is attracting attention due to its high content of sulfur, large reversible capacity (≈1300 mA h g−1), and especially a distinct flat voltage platform, which makes it a quite promising anode material of next-generation LIBs.[206] However, although VS4 possesses a large capacity, its capacity fading is still an urgent and serious issue to be addressed due to the dissolution and diffusion of polysulfide. Furthermore, the voltage platform (≈2.0 V) of VS4 is a little high, even higher than that (≈1.6 V) of Li4Ti5O12, which is safe but causes also the loss of energy density. The above analysis and summary reveal that some other vanadiumbased compounds also exhibit quite attractive potential for energy storage, but some urgent issues and challenges for them need to still be addressed, which suggests that more efforts are worthy to be paid to realize their better applications for energy storage in the future.

metadata.abstractText: With the economic, science and technology increasing at an amazing speed, energy has become one of the most important issues in the 21st century. In addition, the supply of fossil With revolutionary electric vehicles and the smart grid fast developing, more advanced energy storage technologies become quite crucial issues. Li-ion batteries (LIBs) and Na-ion batteries (NIBs) are considered as the most promising electrochemical energy storage technologies. Low-dimensional nano-structural electrode materials can greatly increase the specific capacity, but they still suffer from poor cycling and rate performances due to their serious self-aggregations. Constructing 3D structures, such as micro/ nano-structures and free-standing electrodes, is a quite promising method to address the above issues. Such 3D structures can simultaneously avoid the disadvantages of low-dimensional nanomaterials, and preserve their advantages. As one group of promising high-capacity and low-cost electrode materials, vanadium-based oxides have exhibited an quite attractive electrochemical performance for energy storage applications in many novel works. However, their systematic reviews are quite limited, which is disadvantageous to their further development. Herein, this article provides an overview of vanadium-based oxides in the applications of LIBs and NIBs by focusing mainly on the aspect from low-dimensional nanomaterials synthesis to 3D micro/nano-structures and free-standing electrodes fabrication. Moreover, a feasible strategy to controllably fabricate the 3D micro/nano-structure for the whole vanadium-based oxides family is presented. Furthermore, and importantly, a quite promising solution method for the practical commercialized applications of vanadium oxides cathode materials in the future is proposed, i.e., fabricating the “vanadium oxides-based cathode/solid electrolyte/Li metal anode-type” all solid-state secondary-ion batteries. Energy Storage
